I am a little late to this party, and I admit that I initially picked this book up simply as research for my SF novel set in the year 2074. I felt I needed a reality check. I wanted to know what experts thought the world would actually look like then, since we’re not there now and it’s unlikely I’ll be there to see it when we are.As it turns out, I have gone, and am still going, through many of the phases of denial that the author describes in the first chapter: when I think about climate change at all, it is as something theoretical that I will write about as a science fiction story. Or, I think that there will be a prize-winning technical fix for it, invented by some brilliant wunderkind. Or I think that the Sierra Club and the Nature Conservancy and the World Wildlife Fund, to whom I give money, and the non-climate-change-denying politicians to whom I give my vote, will act on my behalf to slow the effects of greenhouse gas emissions. Or I think that the solar panels we installed on our roof when we moved to California will make a difference.I had even been, wishfully, thinking that things were improving, that worldwide emissions were being slowly reduced due to global agreements made at various climate summits that I read about in the news, but don’t read very carefully, because the particulars of trade negotiations bore me. Distracted by the circus that some people called a Presidential primary in the United States, by both the actuality of terrorism and the mirage of scaremongering about terrorism, and by the particulars of my own life, I had put climate change back in my own mind to being one of many “issues” that I sometimes thought about when I had time and energy to do so.According to this meticulously researched, compelling tour de force of a book, however, I have been wrong. Really, totally, scary wrong. As the author says, climate change due to human-caused carbon emissions has gone from a “grandchildren” problem to a “banging on the door” problem, something that needs to be addressed in the next decade or we face not only the prospect of warmer average temperature in both winters and summers, increased intensity and number of storms and more extreme weather generally, but also the drowning of major cities and even entire nations, the desertification of others, and the displacement and death of millions of people.Some of the interesting, shocking, and potentially hopeful facts she enumerates that are no doubt familiar to many, but which bear repeating here are the following:- The big multinational energy companies have already identified and claimed the right to extract and emit more carbon into the atmosphere than it can safely absorb without triggering catastrophic, unpredictable events (“non-linear tipping elements”) such as the melting of the West Arctic ice sheet or large-scale Amazon dieback.- In wealthy industrialized countries (the US, Canada, and Western Europe), the collapse of Communism has led to a kind of free-market fundamentalism in which economic policy choices are seen in stark, binary terms, with the only “right” choice, called “neoliberalism," leading to ever-higher carbon emissions.- Cap and trade, carbon/emissions credit agreements have been a failure at reducing emissions. Countries are getting carbon “credits” for merely slightly reducing dirty, poisonous practices that they shouldn’t have started doing in the first place. Indigenous people leading sustainable lifestyles in carbon offset areas are being uprooted and forbidden from practicing their livelihoods.- We already have clean energy technology that can make a difference. The biggest problem is deployment and distribution of existing solutions, not a lack of game-changing technologies yet to be invented. For example, renewable energy such as wind and rooftop solar already supplies 25% of Germany’s energy needs. Relatively small shifts in government policy could make these technologies competitive with fossil fuels and also have the benefit of creating more “green" jobs than are lost from the falling away of the fossil fuel extractive industries.- Indigenous peoples' and First Nations' land rights and treaties are some of the last defenses and best hopes for protecting land and have resulted in unlikely alliances between groups with a common interest in protecting land from being exploited, ruined, and poisoned by energy extraction.- Local (city, town, tribal) ownership of the means of energy production and distribution results in a better outcome for everyone than private ownership of these things by large multinational corporations. Several cities in Germany have de-privatized their energy companies and have then made the switch to renewables.- The abolitionist, feminist, and civil rights movements have the best blueprint for social change that a “climate justice” can also be modeled on. Climate justice works in the same direction as these movements, bringing more justice and a better standard of living to historically disenfranchised and exploited people.I don’t have the time or resources to fact check this entire book, but it is extensively footnoted and the sources I am familiar with seem trustworthy to me. The author worked on it for 5 years, employed 2 full-time research assistants, and has attended numerous conferences representing many points of view, all the way from the Heartland Institute who deny any role for human activity in climate change, to the Copenhagen Climate Summit of 2009. But even if some, or many, of the particulars here are found to be incomplete or even wrong, it doesn’t matter. The collective actions recommended in this book would be good for the world, and for its people, even if the climate deadline were not looming so precipitously as Klein thinks.I read this book while traveling in Europe and wrote the bulk of the review on the plane back home to California. I am painfully aware, even as I type this, of the inherent contradictions in that situation. Here I am, writing about the need for reducing carbon emissions as I cross an ocean and a continent in a miraculous yet fossil-fuel-guzzling and carbon-spewing metal tube. Sure, I feel guilty, to the point that I am almost reluctant to write and post this review at all.But I take some hope from the book’s conclusion, which points the only way forward that I can understand, and which I want to keep in mind as I try to finish my climate science fiction novel:“Indeed a great deal of the work of deep social change involves having debates during which new stories can be told to replace the ones that have failed us. . . . (W)e will need to start believing, once again, that humanity is not hopelessly selfish and greedy—the image ceaselessly sold to us by everything from reality shows to neoclassical economics . . . Because in the hot and stormy future we have already made inevitable through our past emissions, an unshakable belief in the equal rights of all people and a capacity for deep compassion will be the only things standing between civilization and barbarism.” (pp. 461-2).

“We are left with a stark choice: allow climate disruption to change everything about our world, or change pretty much everything about our economy to avoid that fate. But we need to be very clear: because of our decades of collective denial, no gradual, incremental options are left to us.”In Naomi Klein’s new book This Changes Everything, she draws a very clear and unsettling picture of where we are headed if we continue to do nothing about climate change. She looks at many of the simplistic solutions put forward and why they fail including individual choices that ignore or deny the socioeconomic conditions that make these untenable for much of the third world. She also shows the hypocrisy of many of the arguments against action: that to do anything would be too expensive; that it’s pointless for the west to do anything if China and India aren’t on side; and the worst hypocrisy of all, it’s too late so what’s the point although this may become a self-fulfilling argument if we don’t change our fossil-fueled addicted ways ASAP. She looks at past and present environmental movements: how many of the older movements were co-opted and what the new movements need to do. And she shows the importance of the Indigenous communities who are leading the climate justice movement and what we can learn from them: "The movements against extreme energy extraction are becoming more than just battles against specific oil, gas, and coal companies and more, even than pro-democracy movements. They are opening up spaces for a historical reconciliation between Indigenous peoples and non-natives, who are finally understanding that, at a time when elected officials have open disdain for basic democratic principles, Indigenous rights are not a threat, but a tremendous gift.”Her book is both unsettling and important. She has a clear, concise way of writing that makes the science and economics easy to understand. But she not only explains the problems, she gives solutions albeit very hard ones. She admits that, while doing researching for the book, the evidence of the devastation doing nothing will cause changed her. She came to the realization that we have left it too long for ‘centrist’ solutions:“the things we must do to avoid catastrophic warming are no longer just in conflict with the particular strain of deregulated capitalism that triumphed in the 1980s. They are now in conflict with the fundamental imperative at the heart of our economic model: grow or die.”This book may not change everything. There will, no doubt, be plenty of people saying she’s gone too far, that her solutions are too ‘radical’. There will still be lots of people that continue to deny the very fact of climate change including commentators on TV trying to prove its non-existence with a glass of water and an ice cube. That’s not likely to change. But, if the recent climate marches around the world are evidence of anything, it’s that there are hundreds of thousands of people who believe in the science of climate change and what it means to our futures and they are no longer asking but demanding change. As Klein points out, climate change is a “civilizational wake-up call. A powerful message – spoken in the language of fires, floods, droughts, and extinctions – telling us that we need an entirely new economic model and a new way of sharing this planet”. And this book makes it clear that we had better wake up soon.

This Changes Everything belongs to the noble tradition of investigative, crusading journalism championed by the likes of Ida Tarbell, Upton Sinclair, Rachel Carson and John Pilger. It is a meticulously researched and passionately argued exposé and a call to arms. Klein spells out in detail the work of the cabal of corporately-funded propaganda houses such as the Heartland and Cato Institutes, and the Heritage Foundation in undermining climate science and subverting what was once a bi-partisan approach to dealing Climate Change. She gives an extended account of the methods and agendas of these groups and provides good insight into their motivations and the reasons for their success in altering public opinion on Climate Change in the last ten years.The strength of this crusading journalism approach is its passion and sense of outrage, the weakness is that it portrays the world as a simplified battle between good guys and bad guys. The bad guys in the this story are the greedy fossil fuel corporations, the extractive coal and oil companies, the white, middle class, right-wing men who are thoroughly invested in the system as it stands. The good guys are the poor and dispossessed of the Earth, the Indigenous Peoples fighting for their rights, the local communities who want to do the right thing if only the political and business elites would allow them to live in harmony with the Earth.The problem with this world view is that while it may be emotionally plausible is it too simplistic. As I can personally attest from my six years working for Shell Wind there are plenty of caring, environmentally committed people working for oil companies, and there are plenty of selfish and greedy people among the supposed "good guys". The world is a more interesting, diverse and challenging place that Klein would have us believe.The other major weakness of the book is the vision of how this Climate Crisis might be dealt with? Klein's view is that only a major bottom-up revolution of attitudes and behavior will stand any chance of making a significant difference. She draws parallels with the abolition of slavery, the end of colonialism, and the Civil Rights Movement in the US. All of these bottom-up movements for societal change had inspirational and charismatic leaders, clear goals and a well-defined program of what needed to be done to achieve them. At the moment this is just not true of the Climate Action movement.Klein may very well be correct in her analysis that the Climate Crisis needs a movement as profound as these, but the examples of Climate Activism she cites seem to be pale imitators of these profound movements towards social justice. She also misses the point that one of the biggest challenges with trying to convince ordinary people of the urgency of the problem is that it seems too vague, diffuse and insubstantial and with only a peripheral impact on their everyday lives.I applaud this book for arguing powerfully the case for immediate and urgent Climate Action now. I worry that the suggested path towards a solution is too Utopian and lacking in real political bite and feasibility.

I feel awfully guilty I didn't post a review sooner - I won this book in a giveaway and thus should have tried to be prompter. But here it goes; fortunately, even two months after reading it, it stands out in my memory quite clearly.I've enjoyed both of Klein's previous books, The Shock Doctrine perhaps slightly more than No Logo, which I think has aged worse, having been written prior to 9/11. But each of them had a powerful and still resonating message, and so does her latest, where Klein lays out her case against the polluters, the politicians who are in the polluters' pockets, the companies that pretend to be green but actually aren't, the carbon offset trading schemes that are anything but helpful (that part was chilling). Much like in her previous books, Klein does her best to suggest solutions alongside with problems; this time, she points to communally-owned power and grassroots movements (including First Nations / Native American groups) that have had some success in preventing the destruction wrought by oil and gas companies.Klein sketches a broad and increasingly radical picture, arguing that the disastrous change of climate we are experiencing is a problem, but it is also an opportunity for communities - for the entire human society - to change radically so as to build a better, more equal, more sustainable future. I am skeptical as to that happening, but certainly wish her positive scenario from this book could prove more true than those from, say, No Logo.And I have to say that while it took me a while to read this book, this was predominantly due to its size, as it was impractical to carry it around, and I did find it very compelling and, at times, a page-turner. I was particularly drawn to Klein's more personal narrative - the chapter about her struggles with infertility was great personal writing.It's the kind of book that might not convince a skeptic denialist (Klein doesn't devote that many pages to proving why and how the climate is changing, she takes this as more or less a given and goes beyond), but that will outrage everyone else. It made me read passages out loud to my s.o. fairly often.

This book doesn't attempt to convince you of the reality of the man-made climate change. If you're a denier or doubter, this book is not for you. That we're heading towards a man-made catastrophe is taken for granted in this book – like when you read Sartre and realize that he's not going to waste his time on such an obvious matter like the nonexistence of God. What Klein wants to discuss here is what we should do to avoid the catastrophe. Forget your pathetic attempts at recycling and saving energy, or the campaigns and conferences of "the Big Green" organizations that rely on donations by big corporations, or the fantastical schemes of a few mad scientists who want to save the world by dimming the sun. Klein calls for nothing short of the overthrow of capitalism as we know it. If the premise of her arguments and her conclusions are corrects, we're doomed. Nay, we're fucked.The book is not convincing if you're a skeptic. And what's worse is that she doesn't really show a path forward other than generalities about the futility of trying to avoid global warming within the confines of unfettered capitalism. She spends large portions of the book detailing the activities of various grass-root movements. These are irrelevant information and do nothing to prove her point – i.e., you can't fix the climate under capitalism – or provide a solution. Personally, I don't have any problem agreeing that mankind has been contributing to global warming, and that the trend is possibly catastrophic. What I can't believe is a bunch of postdocs sitting in a lab and writing C code and claiming that they can predict the long term trajectory of a mind-bogglingly complex system like the global weather. I know enough not to buy it. I've done enough useless simulation at work of far simpler systems.

After first finishing the book, I thought "Well, that was okay." But when I tried to summarize it to my family, it began to sound more and more hollow and obtuse.Klein is a fine writer, but maybe the topic simply defies explanation or a solution - after all, it is clear that the system (capital, corporate democracy, preponderant consumerism, alienation, class exploitation) is not designed to respond to a global crisis like climate change. I think our global plutocrats really believe they live on a planet separate from the rest of us.Klein addresses the relationship between exploitation (from colonialism to globalization) and climate change, and she speaks of the emerging victims of our collective inaction. She trots out some examples of attempts to respond to the issues, and the failures (who really thought billionaires would do anything if they couldn't expropriate surplus value?). And she, rightly, cringes at the techno-fixes proposed by lunatic scientists and engineers to cool the earth after we’ve gone too far.But if our only hope is that First Peoples will use their treaty rights to keep fossil fuels in the ground, well … as they say: hope is just failure with its head in the ground.This Changes Everything is a nice read, but it offers nothing new, and it is too polite. I would have liked a truly revolutionary diatribe (and I think she has a class-struggle-to-change-the-world in her). I have preferred books like Minoru Kyo’s Already Extinct which is a more relentless provocation that creates a landscape barren of false hope.

Years ago, when I was a smug, politically apathetic 21 year old, I read Naomi Klein's 'The Shock Doctrine.'That book changed me as a person: it forced me to think deeply about the history of my country, about how the often toxic economics of the nation I grew up and lived in were inextricably tied in with its often toxic politics. It forced me to confront not just my own ignorance, but my own indifference.'This Changes Everything' is a book that utterly lives up to its title. Klein's goal is nothing less than the imagining of the grandest, global progressive project since the days of Marx and Engels. Klein ranges deep and wide over the current state of climate change: of its brutal, unavoidable scientific causes, of the worthless half-responses that our current socio-economic system has proposed to it, of the numerous voices and movements fighting to root out the resource extraction causing it. It's at once a grand, pain-stakingly precise polemic against our mode of economic and resource existence and simultaneously a stunning, highly practical consideration of the green world we could build with the proper, broad-based social effort.What more can I say? I believe in the kind of world she wants to build. I'm obviously biased given how central her writing has been for my own growth as a politically conscious adult, but I have to recommend this unconditionally.

There is so much one can say about this book and I feel I could go on for a long time about its merits. It is the subject matter rather than the form which is important. You just have to read it, to get it. Capitalism, or our overtly (over)consumer lifestyles don't fit well with an ecological and sustainable view of the finite resources at our present disposal. That is the sum of the book, and Klein offers abundant examples of how this works and some radical suggestions for what we need to be doing about it.I am not one of those who think that Capitalism is evil etc. But I do believe it has built a system that is rapidly coming to its sell-by date, indeed we may have gone beyond that date. Change is required unless this is going to be the footnote in our short evolutionary history. I just hope we stop sleepwalking into what will be a massive crisis of resource, confidence and planning. We need to look at these issues now, instead of awaiting the inevitable, or hoping some techno-fix will help us along. The dystopian science-fiction I also like to read is looking less fictional with every passing year.

Mind Blown.So inspired.Amazing book.Naomi Klein felt much the same way I bet a lot of you do (depressed, like it's too late, already in a state of pre-mourning for all the beautiful things we won't have and our children will never know), before she researched and wrote this book. Through her investigations, she now feels that we really do have a very real chance to prevent catastrophic climate destabilization, but it will need the people to make demands of their governments, to put pressure on the businesses. She lays out very clear and very achievable paths to re-greening our economy and I actually feel very inspired now to be able to help support the changes that need to be made here in my part of the globe. I hope you read the book, because every country has a role to play, and we need people like you, who feel the way that you do, to tell others about this book, and spread the word. Borrow it from a library, buy a copy and share it with your friends, get your hands on it somehow, read and share. And then tell your other friends to read it. We really can make a difference.

I told a dear friend of mine to get me a book by Charles Duhigg when she went to Europe, she ended up getting me this book and boy I'm glad she did.I saw the number of pages and small writing of This Changes Everything and I was wondering after how many years will I ever finish this? but the book grasps your attention with smooth transitions from chapter and chapter and with no effort by the reader to keep up with the stream of knowledge presented by the writer.I would say this book is one of the most important to be read since it deals with a massive problem such as climate change and links it so clearly with dysregulated capitalism as the writer calls it. The book is mostly written in the form of stories, quotes, researches- with a gigantic list of references- as well as the writer's own interpretations. At first you would notice the depth of the hole we humans are in right now, but by the last 100 or so pages of the book the writer shows a whole lot of successful examples on confrontations against the fossil fuel industry and gives the reader a glimpse of hope on our -and my future grandchildren's- future.Definitely 5 stars.

I wanted to like this, but it wasn't meant to be.Things that bothered me:-- Klein seems not to grasp a lot of the science involved, avoiding it completely or using mixed metaphors.-- The author's dismissal of people she disagrees with. They're just 'obviously' wrong. Unless you're chained to a tree with an indigenous group, you're part of the problem, apparently.-- Her dismissal of geoengineering in particular. "It sounds too science fiction, therefore it could never work!" The sulphate idea is an easy one to pick on, and there are risks, but things like algalculture and using seawater to lower the planet's albedo are clearly going to be part of the answer to fighting climate change.On the other hand, the chapter about her trying to get pregnant was interesting just to see her try and justify giving birth to another carbon emitter.Also, I admit I might not be able to look at the problem directly (though I'm no climate change denier) as Paul Kingsnorth's review in the LRB explains: http://www.lrb.co.uk/v36/n20/paul-kin...

Towards a universal theory of social progress, with climate change the catalyst, and a radical approach to aggressive regulation of the fossil fuels industry.I saw Naomi Klein talk recently, and that motivated me to read this book. She made most of her points in the talk, which made reading this book feel like reading about 400 pages of research notes and footnotes. She certainly was able to collect a lot of damning evidence and quotations. It kind of feels like reading about 500 op-eds on the same topic, one after another. A hammer endlessly banging on an anvil.I largely agree with her position, and I think she pushed me to think more radically about my own anti-oil position. But she accomplished that with her 1hr talk. Reading this book did not add that much. I don't think I will bother watching the TV documentary. Maybe I should have just watched that instead.If someone asks me "what is the big deal, why should I care? Can you recommend a SINGLE book to lay out everything?" then I will definitely recommend this book. Though I wouldn't expect anyone to actually finish it.

How many things can American conservatives be completely wrong about while still spewing their mindlessly inaccurate slogans? How many times are they going to change the goalposts as far as their stance on climate change? It isn’t happening, it won’t ever happen, it’s happening but it isn’t our fault, it’s our fault but doing anything would ruin the economy, or immigrants are to blame. Another important book by Klein who seems to be one of the few conscious people in our culture. Here’s the thing, I don’t have kids so why do I give a shit about the planet? In fact, I have about the greenest lifestyle of anyone in the western world. It’s not because I’m some sort of hippie, I chose my lifestyle because it makes my life better. I live without a car, heat, air conditioning (lovely climate here), and I don’t buy every consumer gadget that comes down the pike. As she says in the book, no one is coming to save us, people. We need to wake the fuck up and take back our world.

Just finished reading Naomi Klein's new book 'This Changes Everything'. It's not a perfect book but it will definitely be one of the most important books you've ever read. For progressives and enviro conscious people it lays out a very clear and compelling argument that addressing climate change has to mean challenging the fundamentals of capitalism. This challenge can only come about through serious, mass, powerful, diverse, international, multi-faceted social movements. To lefties and people already convinced that the world needs to be radically changed to achieve global justice and decolonisation Klein outlines how these struggles can be/are already linked to a new, necessary global metanarrative of saving the planet through achieving global climate justice. This is the 'Idea' we've been looking for. Can't recommend it highly enough.

It's unbelievable how many words it takes to say so little in this book. I listened to the whole thing thinking eventually it would get to interesting scientific facts about how to improve the energy industry and fight climate change. Instead, it's almost entirely emotional name-calling and pep-talking for grass-roots organization and protesting. I understand the downsides of capitalism and cronyism and the effects it has on the environment so I wasn't reading this to learn that. This is not a book about technologies that can help fight climate change, so don't come looking for that. If you're looking to be motivated to hate capitalism and join the fight for climate change this might be a good book for you. For me, I'm looking to read more about possible solutions (other than "the status quo is the devil we need a revolution") and this was not it.

It took me awhile to read this for two reasons. One, there is much to digest and think about. And two, there are sections that made me so angry that I had to take a break. Klein looks at climate change and why it has been so difficult for us to address it. Everything from finding the problem so overwhelming that we ignore it, to waiting for a technological solution, to hoping a billionaire will ride to our rescue, to having to find a way around the free market ideology that causes entrenched political and economic power. She describes some of the local battles, many fought by indigenous peoples, that have had some success. She hopes that our collective will and fight for justice for post colonial societies will carry the day. Klein thinks we need to be prepared to act when a spark inspires collective action. So we hope and prepare.

Klein has a way of writing about big issues- this time climate chaos and the multitude of existing or non existing policies that are needed to stop catastrophic CO2 rising- that is compelling and engaging. As someone who has been making climate justice documentaries for a while (one of my films is sourced in the notes in the carbon market section) I’ve obviously read and thought a lot on this topic and yet, I didn’t find the book material old, or that I already ‘knew’ all the content, although I am familiar and full support with the arguments and solutions put forward, it was really great to find it all under one very well written book. Highly recommend.

This is a powerful book about climate change. Klein argues that our current economic system cannot solve this problem. The last time we had to make an economic change of this magnitude is no less than the abolition of slavery. The companies who are reliant on fossil fuels will not go down easily. The necessary changes must start from the grassroots level, or what Klein calls "Blockistan," and momentum has already started as evidenced by the fight against Keystone XL and natural gas fracking. Highly recommended.

I, typically, do not give 5 star reviews. This was not earth shattering material. I was well aware of climate change. Not a denier, but perhaps a a certain amount of selective listening or slightly ignoring going on. What was startling was Klein's take on the seedy underbelly of some root causes, solutions, and the indictment of capitalism as a whole. Worth your time. Worth the harsh self examination you will do afterwards. You do not have to agree with everything she says to understand gravity of problem and the consequences of the solution and doing nothing. Read it.

I'll echo another reviewer: "Not perfect, but too important to give less than 5 stars." I feel the same.My mother didn't know who Naomi Klein was, and in describing her I said: "You know to the extent that Stephen Harper grosses us out and makes us embarrassed he's Canadian? Well that much in the opposite direction for Naomi Klein, she's great."

The scope of 'This Changes Everything' is pretty impressive, covering the basics of environmental science, the history of the environmentalist movement, the politics of energy, the complex world of climate justice, and some proposals for how we can fix society such that preventing catastrophic climate change is possible. In a sense, it tries to be to the issue of climate change as The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer is to cancer, although in my view it isn't entirely successful.As an introduction to the topic, 'This Changes Everything' is useful, albeit long. Naomi Klein is a brilliant storyteller, but The Uninhabitable Earth: Life After Warming gives you an overview of the issues with an awful lot less padding. Klein makes a useful critique of the efforts thus far to preserve the environment, in particular the spurious role of 'hero capitalists' like Richard Branson. However, in promoting strategies for a future environmentalism, she isn't interested in anything that doesn't support her ideal semi-anarchistic societal form of non-hierarchical communities democratically organising their own renewable-powered micro-grids. On the one hand, she upholds Blockadia's direct action tactics as the model for opposing the fossil fuel industry, and yet on the other hand she's completely dismissive of China - a large, centrally-organised state power that is doing more to promote renewable energy and meet its emissions targets than the rest of the world put together. I support direct action on climate change, but it's important to recognise the limitations to its effectiveness, and also to note that it's mainly the preserve of a privileged few that don't have to worry about putting food on the table.This imbalance in the book relates to a vision that sees climate change (correctly) as a political problem, but isn't willing to engage with the most important questions within politics: political power and class forces. As such, the author is searching for solutions that don't meaningfully affect the balance of forces. Why is China so much more responsive than the US or Britain to the needs of the planet? Because, whatever one thinks of it, China's government isn't beholden to large corporations, and it seeks legitimacy from its wider population. Why has the US pulled out of the Paris Agreement? Because its government is in the pockets of the oil companies. This is a political problem, that can only be solved through political struggle (in the case of the US, the obvious path forward in the present period is to unite all progressive forces around a left-wing presidential candidate and hold them to account to push through a Green New Deal).Again, because of her fondness for decentralisation, Klein rules out any kind of nuclear power, but lauds the various experiments with democratic micro-grids in Germany. But how is this playing out in reality? Since starting to phase out nuclear power, Germany's CO2 emissions have been going up, because it's been replacing nuclear power with fracked shale gas - a CO2-emitting fossil fuel. This is an absurd state of affairs. As David Wallace-Wells points out: "Already, more than 10,000 people die from air pollution daily. That is considerably more each day than the total number of people who have ever been affected by the meltdowns of nuclear reactors." I'm fairly ambivalent in relation to nuclear power in general - the dangers are real enough, it's expensive, and renewables are much more promising - but it's quite obviously not the right thing to push it out of the energy mix before renewables are ready to fully take over.The book also has some unnecessary and slightly confused ideological fluff. We're presented with a dichotomy of extractivism and regenerationism; a capitalist vs an indigenous way of thinking and being. This tends to ignore the very real benefits that 'extractivism' has brought. It's not about 'extracting' per se, but about how liberating chemical energy from hydrocarbons has allowed some extraordinary improvements in the quality of human life. That we can travel, that we can reasonably expect to live well into our 80s, that we can survive any number of illnesses, that we have books, computers, running water, hot showers, schools, libraries, hospitals... all these things exist thanks to our ability to channel the universe's energy. These days of course we can 'extract' energy in other ways - kinetic energy from the wind and sea, heat energy from the sun, nuclear energy from atoms - but this represents a deeper understanding of science rather than a retreat from scientific engagement with the planet. What's certainly true is that we need to understand our environment better and engage with it in a more careful and sustainable way, but IMHO the idea of a philosophical shift away from 'extractivism' is a red herring.Altogether an interesting and worthwhile book, but significantly flawed.

“Climate change has become an existential crisis for the human species. The only historical precedent for a crisis of this depth and scale was the Cold War fear that we were heading toward nuclear holocaust, which would have made much of the planet uninhabitable. But that was (and remains) a threat; a slim possibility, should geopolitics spiral out of control. The vast majority of nuclear scientists never told us that we were almost certainly going to put our civilization in peril if we kept going about our daily lives as usual, doing exactly what we were already doing, which is what the climate scientists have been telling us for years.Power from renewable sources like wind and water predates the use of fossil fuels and is becoming cheaper, more efficient, and easier to store every year. The past two decades have seen an explosion of ingenious zero-waste design, as well as green urban planning. Not only do we have the technical tools to get off fossil fuels, we also have no end of small pockets where these low carbon lifestyles have been tested with tremendous success. And yet the kind of large-scale transition that would give us a collective chance of averting catastrophe eludes us.My mind keeps coming back to the question: what is wrong with us? What is really preventing us from putting out the fire that is threatening to burn down our collective house? I think the answer is far more simple than many have led us to believe: we have not done the things that are necessary to lower emissions because those things fundamentally conflict with deregulated capitalism, the reigning ideology for the entire period we have been struggling to find a way out of this crisis.We are stuck because the actions that would give us the best chance of averting catastrophe—and would benefit the vast majority—are extremely threatening to an elite minority that has a stranglehold over our economy, our political process, and most of our major media outlets. That problem might not have been insurmountable had it presented itself at another point in our history. But it is our great collective misfortune that the scientific community made its decisive diagnosis of the climate threat at the precise moment when those elites were enjoying more unfettered political, cultural, and intellectual power than at any point since the 1920s.Indeed, governments and scientists began talking seriously about radical cuts to greenhouse gas emissions in 1988 — the exact year that marked the dawning of what came to be called “globalization,” with the signing of the agreement representing the world’s largest bilateral trade relationship between Canada and the United States, later to be expanded into the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) with the inclusion of Mexico.When historians look back on the past quarter century of international negotiations, two defining processes will stand out. There will be the climate process: struggling, sputtering, failing utterly to achieve its goals. And there will be the corporate globalization process, zooming from victory to victory: from that first free trade deal to the creation of the World Trade Organization to the mass privatization of the former Soviet economies to the transformation of large parts of Asia into sprawling free-trade zones to the “structural adjusting” of Africa.The three policy pillars of this new era are familiar to us all: privatization of the public sphere, deregulation of the corporate sector, and lower corporate taxation, paid for with cuts to public spending. Much has been written about the real-world costs of these policies—the instability of financial markets, the excesses of the super-rich, and the desperation of the increasingly disposable poor, as well as the failing state of public infrastructure and services.Very little, however, has been written about how market fundamentalism has, from the very first moments, systematically sabotaged our collective response to climate change, a threat that came knocking just as this ideology was reaching its zenith.The core problem was that the stranglehold that market logic secured over public life in this period made the most direct and obvious climate responses seem politically heretical. How, for instance, could societies invest massively in zero-carbon public services and infrastructure at a time when the public sphere was being systematically dismantled and auctioned off? How could governments heavily regulate, tax, and penalize fossil fuel companies when all such measures were being dismissed as relics of “command and control” communism? And how could the renewable energy sector receive the supports and protections it needed to replace fossil fuels when “protectionism” had been made a dirty word?A different kind of climate movement would have tried to challenge the extreme ideology that was blocking so much sensible action, joining with other sectors to show how unfettered corporate power posed a grave threat to the habitability of the planet. Instead, large parts of the climate movement wasted precious decades attempting to make the square peg of the climate crisis fit into the round hole of deregulated capitalism, forever touting ways for the problem to be solved by the market itself.But blocking strong climate action wasn’t the only way that the triumph of market fundamentalism acted to deepen the crisis in this period. Even more directly, the policies that so successfully freed multinational corporations from virtually all constraints also contributed significantly to the underlying cause of global warming—rising greenhouse gas emissions. The numbers are striking: in the 1990s, as the market integration project ramped up, global emissions were going up an average of 1 percent a year; by the 2000s, with “emerging markets” like China now fully integrated into the world economy, emissions growth had sped up disastrously, with the annual rate of increase reaching 3.4 percent a year for much of the decade. That rapid growth rate continues to this day, interrupted only briefly in 2009 by the world financial crisis.With hindsight, it’s hard to see how it could have turned out otherwise. The twin signatures of this era have been the mass export of products across vast distances (relentlessly burning carbon all the way), and the import of a uniquely wasteful model of production, consumption, and agriculture to every corner of the world (also based on the profligate burning of fossil fuels). Put differently, the liberation of world markets, a process powered by the liberation of unprecedented amounts of fossil fuels from the earth, has dramatically sped up the same process that is liberating Arctic ice from existence.As a result, we now find ourselves in a very difficult and slighty ironic position. Because of those decades of hardcore emitting exactly when we were supposed to be cutting back, the things we must do to avoid catastrophic warming are no longer just in conflict with the particular strain of deregulated capitalism that triumphed in the 1980s. They are now in conflict with the fundamental imperative at the heart of our economic model: grow or die. Once carbon has been emitted into the atmosphere, it sticks around for hundreds of years, some of it even longer, trapping heat. The effects are cumulative, growing more severe with time.Our economic system and our planetary system are now at war. Or, more accurately, our economy is at war with many forms of life on earth, including human life. What the climate needs to avoid collapse is a contraction in humanity’s use of resources; what our economic model demands to avoid collapse is unfettered expansion.By posing climate change as a battle between capitalism and the planet, I am not saying anything that we don’t already know. The battle is already under way, but right now capitalism is winning hands down. It wins every time the need for economic growth is used as the excuse for putting off climate action yet again, or for breaking emission reduction commitments already made. It wins when Greeks are told that their only path out of economic crisis is to open up their beautiful seas to high-risk oil and gas drilling. It wins when Canadians are told our only hope of not ending up like Greece is to allow our boreal forests to be flayed so we can access the semisolid bitumen from the Alberta tar sands. It wins when a park in Istanbul is slotted for demolition to make way for yet another shopping mall. It wins when parents in Beijing are told that sending their wheezing kids to school in pollution masks decorated to look like cute cartoon characters is an acceptable price for economic progress. It wins every time we accept that we have only bad choices available to us: austerity or extraction, poisoning or poverty.The challenge, then, is not simply that we need to spend a lot of money and change a lot of policies; it’s that we need to think differently, radically differently, for those changes to be remotely possible. Right now, the triumph of market logic, with its ethos of domination and fierce competition, is paralyzing almost all serious efforts to respond to climate change.Climate change isn’t an “issue” to add to the list of things to worry about, next to health care and taxes. It is a civilizational wake-up call. A powerful message—spoken in the language of fires, floods, droughts, and extinctions—telling us that we need an entirely new economic model and a new way of sharing this planet. Telling us that we need to evolve.It’s too late to stop climate change from coming; it is already here, and increasingly brutal disasters are headed our way no matter what we do. But it’s not too late to avert the worst, and there is still time to change ourselves so that we are far less brutal to one another when those disasters strike. And that, it seems to me, is worth a great deal. Because the thing about a crisis this big, this all-encompassing, is that it changes everything.”NAOMI KLEIN,This Changes Everything

This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. The Climate by Naomi Klein“This Changes Everything” is a comprehensive book that covers the crisis of climate change and the historic opportunity it will provide to restructure the globe. Award-winning journalist and best-selling author Naomi Klein proposes a different strategy that requires a cultural shift in order to implement sensible policies to save the planet. This book explores the changes on the social side as well as the political, economic and cultural sides. This thorough 577-page book includes thirteen chapters and it’s broken out into the following three parts: 1. Bad Timing, 2. Magical Thinking, and Starting Anyway.Positives:1.	High-quality researched book. It’s well written and thorough.2.	A critical topic in the hands of an award-winning journalist. Klein is a keen observer and her exhaustive research is reflected in her great work.3.	Most of the books I’ve read on climate change focus on the science, this book focuses on the societal implications and it does so comprehensively. There are few stones left unturned. 4.	Klein spent a lot of time investigating, interviewing subject matter experts and sharing thoughts and ideas. This is no rush job.5.	Exposes the misinformation machine that is the Heartland Institute. “But most of all, I will hear versions of the opinion expressed by the county commissioner in the fourth row: that climate change is a Trojan horse designed to abolish capitalism and replace it with some kind of ‘green communitarianism.’” 6.	So what’s the driving force behind climate change denialism? “More fundamentally than any of this, though, is their deep fear that if the free market system really has set in motion physical and chemical processes that, if allowed to continue unchecked, threaten large parts of humanity at an existential level, then their entire crusade to morally redeem capitalism has been for naught. With stakes like these, clearly greed is not so very good after all. And that is what is behind the abrupt rise in climate change denial among hardcore conservatives: they have come to understand that as soon as they admit that climate change is real, they will lose the central ideological battle of our time—whether we need to plan and manage our societies to reflect our goals and values, or whether that task can be left to the magic of the market.”7.	Does a wonderful job of defining new terms and keeps the book accessible throughout. “Based on this research, Kahan and others argue, environmentalists should sell climate action by playing up concerns about national security and emphasizing responses such as nuclear power and “geoengineering”—global-scale technological interventions that would attempt to reverse rapid warming by, for instance, blocking a portion of the sun’s rays, or by “fertilizing” the oceans so that they trap more carbon, among other untested, extraordinarily high-risk schemes.” 8.	Interesting perspectives. ‘The popular climate blogger Joe Romm, for instance, writes that “if you hate government intrusion into people’s lives, you’d better stop catastrophic global warming, because nothing drives a country more towards activist government than scarcity and deprivation. . . . Only Big Government—which conservatives say they don’t want—can relocate millions of citizens, build massive levees, ration crucial resources like water and arable land, mandate harsh and rapid reductions in certain kinds of energy—all of which will be inevitable if we don’t act now.’”9.	Provides many details on how we wound up in the situation that we are in. “Indeed the three policy pillars of the neoliberal age—privatization of the public sphere, deregulation of the corporate sector, and the lowering of income and corporate taxes, paid for with cuts to public spending—are each incompatible with many of the actions we must take to bring our emissions to safe levels. And together these pillars form an ideological wall that has blocked a serious response to climate change for decades.”10.	The impact of free trade. “That changed with the advent of free trade: thanks to the removal of virtually all barriers to capital flows, corporations could pick up and leave every time labor costs started rising.”11.	Facts throughout the book. “The fossil fuel companies have known for decades that their core product was warming the planet, and yet they have not only failed to adapt to that reality, they have actively blocked progress at every turn. Meanwhile, oil and gas companies remain some of the most profitable corporations in history, with the top five oil companies pulling in $900 billion in profits from 2001 to 2010. ExxonMobil still holds the record for the highest corporate profits ever reported in the United States, earning $41 billion in 2011 and $45 billion in 2012. These companies are rich, quite simply, because they have dumped the cost of cleaning up their mess onto regular people around the world. It is this situation that, most fundamentally, needs to change.”12.	Provides many ideas to counter climate change. “Progressives can easily do the same: by showing that the real solutions to the climate crisis are also our best hope of building a much more stable and equitable economic system, one that strengthens and transforms the public sphere, generates plentiful, dignified work, and radically reins in corporate greed.”13.	Fracking in perspective, what the frack? “The study found that methane emissions linked to fracked natural gas are at least 30 percent higher than the emissions linked to conventional gas. That’s because the fracking process is leaky—methane leaks at every stage of production, processing, storage, and distribution.”14.	The sad reality that green billionaires won’t save us and why that is. Klein really shows off her investigative chops here. An expose of sorts. Branson, Buffett, Gates…15.	A fascinating look at geoengineering. A great job of peeling back the onion on this fascinating topic. “When that happens, the sulfuric acid droplets don’t fall back down: they remain in the stratosphere, and within weeks can circulate to surround the entire planet. The droplets act like tiny, light-scattering mirrors, preventing the full heat of the sun from reaching the planet’s surface. When these larger volcanic eruptions occur in the tropics, the aerosols stay suspended in the stratosphere for roughly one to two years, and the global cooling effects can last even longer.”16.	The last great hope blockadia. “Blockadia is not a specific location on a map but rather a roving transnational conflict zone that is cropping up with increasing frequency and intensity wherever extractive projects are attempting to dig and drill, whether for open-pit mines, or gas fracking, or tar sands oil pipelines.”17.	Great stories throughout the book. “For instance, one of the natural gas industry’s biggest strategic mistakes was deciding it wanted to frack in and around Ithaca, New York—a liberal college town with a vibrant economic localization movement and blessed with breathtaking gorges and waterfalls. Faced with a direct threat to its idyllic community, Ithaca became not just a hub for anti-fracking activism but a center for serious academic research into the unexplored risks: it’s likely no coincidence that researchers at Cornell University, based in Ithaca, produced the game-changing study on methane emissions linked to fracking, whose findings became an indispensable tool for the global resistance movement.”18.	Recounts many carbon disasters. “Unforgettable images from the bizarre underwater “spill-cam” showing BP’s oil gushing for three long months into the Gulf merge seamlessly with shocking footage of methane-laced tap water being set on fire in fracking country, which in turn meld with the grief of Quebec’s Lac-Mégantic after the horrific train explosion, with family members searching through the rubble for signs of their loved ones, which in turn fade to memories of 300,000 people in West Virginia being told they could not drink or bathe in their tap water for up to ten days after it had been contaminated by chemicals used in coal mining. And then there was the spectacle in 2012 of Shell’s first foray into the highest-risk gambit of all: Arctic drilling.”19. Naomi Klein's epic exploration of the specific causes and dire effects of climate change on our world right now and in the coming decades--as well as an inspiring portrait of the people and movements who are are doing things today to help ward off or at least ease what looks like certain, catastrophic, system-wide failure--may only be a 4-star reading experience, but I give it, like, 40 stars in terms of importance. Make that 400. Like her previous books No Logo and Shock Doctrine, both of which remain completely relevant and which I highly recommend (she's basically my hero), This Changes Everything is sharp, smart, exhaustively researched, and relentless in its indictment of unregulated global capitalism as the primary and immediate force behind all of the world's woes. There's no one who shouldn't read it, but in case you are unlikely to do so, here are three salient points: 1. The "tell that to China, the US and EU are cutting CO2 emissions!" mentality is not only dangerously selfish, but also dead wrong. First, the level of CO2 in the atmosphere today is a cumulative measure from centuries of emissions, so even if China were pouring out more CO2 this week, the US, for example, has contributed vastly more to the problem since industrialization. We are not off the hook. Equally important, most measures of current CO2 output don't take into consideration the drivers of production. If an American company farms out all of its manufacturing to China, which then ships in raw materials, makes the goods, then ships everything halfway around the world (puffing out CO2 all the way) where you, the American consumer, buys them (and probably throws them away shorty after, clogging the landfills), who's CO2 balance sheet should that go on? China's, or the USA's? I'm sure you can guess which side American PR firms, climate change deniers, and corporate apologists put it on. Likewise, if an American company excavates coal (burning huge amounts of CO2 and poisoning the landscape all the while) and imports it to China to burn, banking huge profits and making a very few people outrageously wealthy, how is the US company in that scene not the culpable party? 2. We have to all start screaming "bullshit" every time we hear that technology or "geo-engineering" is going to save us, no need to change anything, just keep letting corporations make ridiculous amounts of money at your expense. To take just one small example, rather than pouring resources and the world's best minds into switching over to wind and solar power--which could, in fact, provide 100% of our electricity with 20 years if we really do it--the rich and powerful are instead moving forward with such insanely horrible ideas like blasting huge amounts of sulfuric acid and sulfur dioxide into the upper atmosphere to dim the sun. That's right, rather than give up their fossil-fuel profits, they'd prefer to try and form a chemical dome around the whole planet to block out the sun. What could go wrong with that? 3. Speaking of bullshit: everything fossil fuel and extraction companies say about how they ARE investing in and moving toward alternative energy sources... it's all total lies. The companies, because they are more concerned with non-stop record growth and profits that are the hallmarks of capitalism today (and, so, making more money than they could ever possibly spend), are not only sitting on "proven reserves"--oil and gas in the ground that has been not yet been extracted, but is put on their books--that add up to FIVE TIMES the highest amount we can use and not destroy the planet once and for all, but they are also right now throwing huge amounts of money on extremely risky and out-and-out harmful extraction methods such as deep-sea and Arctic drilling, as well as tar sands and fracking. That's in addition to all of the WAAAAAAY too much fossil fuels they already have in reserve. They don't care if tens of millions people die in the coming decades because of climate-change-induced drought and crop failure and starvation, ocean acidification wiping out fish stocks, ever-more-severe storms, and, of course, sea levels rising to the point where vast patches of hugely populated areas will become uninhabitable. They don't care! All they care about is money. Anyway, Klein is much more intelligent than I am, and she tells the story clearly and forcefully in This Changes Everything. Klein does teeter on despair (like me), about how anyone, any government, any movement, will be able to force the sort of radical change required, upon our whole global, unregulated, free-trade, capitalist economic system, before it's too TOO late (it's already too late, but let's hope we can salvage the rest?). And, of course, the change has to happen right now. But there are some hopeful signs around the world, as energy companies get too greedy and go after fossil fuel in areas where people are NOT poor and already marginalized, and the wealthy and white start to fight back. Also, indigenous peoples in several keys areas of North and South America actually have the law on their side, in terms of stopping pipelines and shipping channels and other distribution methods for some of the most toxic fuels, like tar sands and fracked gas. Whether they can get the companies to obey the law is another matter. And, frankly, I think Klein is too soft on consumer culture, which drives so much of all of the above, our sense of entitlement that we should be able to drive and fly anywhere, and buy everything, even--especially!--stuff we don't need but just maybe want for two seconds before tiring of it and so buying something else, even if we're feeding the very beast that will soon destroy us. We are GORGING it with our buying habits. Imagine if everyone in America cut their fuel consumption in half, starting today. And bought only a third of the consumer goods this season that they purchased last season. Both are easy to do, not at all painful. It just requires a willingness to change: our attitudes, our habits, our daily routines, our priorities. Let's hope humanity can pull it off.

A truly edifying read. Naomi Klein is very astute indeed. I feel much more aware of the enormous issues we face and the mammoth task at hand to halt (and hopefully reverse some of) the damage done, but in many ways still pretty daunted despite the (measured-but-)hopeful conclusion. But that's not going to stop me from showing up where I'm needed, divesting where I'm able and supporting the things that need to be supported for a better future wherever possible for me to do so.I would highly recommend this well-researched resource. It will appeal to those already convinced of the arguments, but the point is not to convince deniers (who are considered almost irrelevant in all this). The point is to arm would-be-activists with information, showing possible next steps, and it is very successful at that.

The changing climate really does change everything: even if we should be more positive about the general state of the world (see Factfulness: Ten Reasons We're Wrong About the World – and Why Things Are Better Than You Think, by Hans Rosling), we are destroying our own planet very fast.Naomi Klein punches you in the stomach: climate change is the big challenge of our time and goes much further than your worst fears. It is not just about adapting a little bit, becoming more energy efficient, producing less waste, no. Everything has to change about our "extractive" consumerist lives: we have to reinvent the very base of our modern societies, start viewing life in different ways (read circular, harmony, regeneration), dismantle the current system and start all over again. Create real and inclusive democracies, eradicate inequalities. Plus, we don't have time: we have to act now.Then the book depresses you as it goes on and on about the power of the extractive industry and big oil and how their grip on power inhibits any political change. So you start to hope for some technological fixes that at least can buy us more time? Klein is very clear about that: fixing the climate by geoengineering is an illusion. Worse: it probably will only make things worse.Luckily, there is part three of the book: Starting anyway. In this part, Klein gives the reader hope and energy to act. Blockadia shows how resistance builds up, in surprising ways and in unexpected places. It is clear: we need mass movements, engaged citizens, regenerate the commons, reinvent the world.Even though the book was a bit too long and for me too much focused on the US and Canada, it did succeed in shaking me awake and convince me once more on the urgency to act.

A couple weeks before reading this book I watched the movie First Reformed. And since watching, there hasn't been a single day that I haven't thought of that film. First Reformed covers a lot of topics, one of the main ones being dread and despair about climate change and ecological destruction. I find it so hard to remain both optimistic and realistic about the future of the planet. I think it's especially hard for a book to strike that balance, yet I think Naomi Klein achieves it in this book. This Changes Everything has me convinced. Capitalism is directly opposed to stopping warming and preventing catastrophe, and it's sad to think that our politics and economy is structured in a way that will allow millions of people to die, countless species to go extinct, and immeasurable damage to occur simply to serve capital and those who have power. Ursula K Le Guin said "We live in capitalism. Its power seems inescapable," and that's a sentiment present in much of this book. But I think Naomi Klein does a great job of including just enough hope and reason for optimism. Through both her personal stories and the stories of those fighting for real change, I'm left with at least some feeling that things can get better. This book shows that the climate fight intersects with so many topics: indigenous rights, eliminating poverty, racial justice, the list is endless. And it's this interconnectedness which can build solidarity, and inspire people to come together. The full quote from Ursula K Le Guin is: “We live in capitalism. Its power seems inescapable. So did the divine right of kings. Any human power can be resisted and changed by human beings.”. This book is a reminder of the power that people have, it's a reminder of the hope that we should continue to believe in.

Naomi Klein's 
"This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs The Climate"
 is a very powerful, fascinating, meticulously sourced, more thesis driven than readable (for the masses) book. (It took me a while to go through this book because I kept going back to the source material to learn more). Much of what I read prior to purchasing the book slammed Klein for being anti-capitalist. This is actually not a book that is purely against capitalism and if that's what you think it is, drop that notion now. It's not a treatise against capitalism but IS a call to arms to come together, as a global community to change the course for our own collective well-being. Klein is seeking a ecological-cultural revolution and spells it out plainly WHY we need one. Klein highlighted incredibly scary climate numbers, stories from other countries about their battles with Big Oil as well as some remarkable successes, she uncovered the depth of corruption in the oil and gas (extractivist companies) and how much their dirty fossil fuel money lined the pockets of politicians including some environmental groups. (In fact, one incredibly shocking piece was that an environment trust group was actually running a drilling project on the land they had been tasked to protect!! How absolutely insane is that!?)Klein cited so much material that it was overwhelming but it was necessary to read and it's necessary for all of us to wake-up to what is happening around us and to empower ourselves to make a change.I think we are certainly at the cross-winds and I am left with no choice but to hold out hope that we can move forward, that there will be a catalyst so strong that will come crashing down and force people power (think of the Occupy Movement in 2011). I cannot imagine the world watching ANOTHER oil spill like the BP Gulf spill without having a visceral reaction and being moved enough to react louder and more clear. (The data out of the Gulf is still coming out documenting the damage to wildlife and will continue to raise alarms. There is a section of the fertility rates of species in damaged areas which was interesting.)I read an article last night that indicated 2012 was the hottest year globally on record. I read another one written afterwards that confirmed that 2014 was in fact, the hottest year on record. And we know that the weather is more drastic, we are seeing the polar ice caps melt, too many species going extinct than we can wrap our brains around, severe drought, mass die-offs, loss of agricultural lands, massive pollution, reduced air quality, water quality, health issues and on and on.There is no denying the science. As Klein indicated, 97% of the worlds' scientists have confirmed climate change. Climate deniers have succeeded only because they were supported by the deep pockets of oil and gas (and strongly influenced the media over the last several years - at least in North America - so we wouldn't hear as much about the issue. Those statistics were alarming as well but we all already know that special interest groups have far-reaching power over our mainstream news sources). These groups include the Heartland Institute and foundations supported by the Koch brothers. The information about the Koch brothers was fascinating, in addition to that some of the quotes that various deniers made were so shockingly negative about the climate and the earth in general that it was mind-blowing! I mean, they do LIVE on this planet and have presumably enjoyed some element of the natural world, right??The time most certainly IS now. The following is excerpted from the article, Crossing the River of Fire written by John Bellamy Foster."A return to a lower per capita output (in GDP terms) could be made feasible with redistribution of income and wealth, social planning, decreases in working time, and universal satisfaction of genuine human needs (a sustainable environment; clean air and water; ample food, clothing, and shelter; and high-quality health care, education, public transportation, and community-cultural life) such that most people would experience a substantial improvement in their daily lives.16 What Klein envisions here would truly be an ecological-cultural revolution. All that is really required, since the necessary technological means already exist, is people power: the democratic mass mobilization of the population."http://monthlyreview.org/2015/02/01/c...At the very core of my being, I wish to be alive and able to see this transformation take place.
