This book is powerful and prophetic. We need to kick into gear now, yesterday, ten lifetimes ago.* A few of the passages that caught me by the throat:Page 88, We have an economic system that fetishizes GDP growth above all else, regardless of the human or ecological consequences, while failing to place value on those things that most of us cherish above all - a decent standard of living, a measure of future security, and our relationships with one another . . . there is still time to avoid catastrophic warming, but not within the rules of capitalism as they are currently constructed . . . /p.89/ [The problem is that, for many of us] changing the earth's climate in ways that will be chaotic and disastrous is easier to accept than the prospect of changing the fundamentally growth-based, profit-seeking logic of capitalism.Page 148, In 2011, a think tank in London called the Carbon Tracker Initiative conducted a breakthrough study that added together the reserves claimed by all the fossil fuel companies, private and state-owned. It found that the oil, gas, and coal to which these players had already laid claim—deposits they have on their books and which were already making money for shareholders—represented 2,795 gigatons of carbon dioxide (a gigaton is 1 billion metric tons). That’s a very big problem because we know roughly how much carbon can be burned between now and 2050 and still leave us a solid chance (roughly 80 percent) of keeping warming below 2 degrees Celsius. According to one highly credible study, that amount of carbon dioxide is 565 gigatons between 2011 and 2049. And as Bill McKibben points out, “The thing to notice is, 2,795 is five times 565. It’s not even close.” He adds: “What those numbers mean is quite simple. This industry has announced, in filings to the SEC and in promises to shareholders, that they’re determined to burn five times more fossil fuel than the planet’s atmosphere can begin to absorb."Those numbers also tell us that the very thing we must do to avert catastrophe—stop digging—is the very thing these companies cannot contemplate without initiating their own demise. They tell us that getting serious about climate change, which means cutting our emissions radically, is simply not compatible with the continued existence of one of the most profitable industries in the world.Page 158-9, Western culture has worked very hard to erase Indigenous cosmologies that call on the past and the future to interrogare present-day actions, with long-dead ancestors always present, alongside the generations yet to corne.In short: more bad timing. Just when we needed to slow down and notice the subtle changes in the natural world that are telling us that something is seriously amiss, we have sped up; just when we needed longer time horizons to see how the actions of our past impact the prospects for our future, we entered into the never-ending feed of the perpetual now, slicing and dicing our attention spans as never before.To understand how we got to this place of profound disconnection from our surroundings and one another, and to think about how we might build a politics based on reconnection, we will need to go back a good deal further than 1988. Because the truth is that, while contemporary, hyper-globalizedcapitalism has exacerbated the climate crisis, it did not create it. We started treating the atmosphere as our waste dump when we began using coal on a commercial scale in the late 1700s and engaged in similarly reckless ecological practices well before that.Moreover, humans have behaved in this shortsighted way not only under capitalist systems, but under systems that called themselves socialist as well (whether they were or not remains a subject of debate). Indeed the roots of the climate crisis date back to core civilizational myths on whichpost-Enlightenment Western culture is founded—myths about humanity’s duty to dominate a natural world that is believed to be at once limitless and entirely controllable. This is not a problem that can be blamed on the political right or on the United States; these are powerful cultural narratives that transcend geography and ideological divides.*Bicycle gears, of course.

I consumed most of the audiobook of This Changes Everything while driving my Prius to my job in the environmental field, and finished it while sipping kombucha made in Portland and working in my 21st century East Vancouver victory garden, on a day when I'd also walked to the farmer's market to purchase locally sourced kale plants to add to my garden. I've been struggling lately with the feeling that it's the end of the world because of climate change, spineless politicians, corruption, and so on. So, I really wanted some answers from Naomi Klein on how to make things better. She has some good things to say (along with a lot of alarming ones), but what I get out of this book is that it essentially boils down to us all having to declare a revolution while hoping that indigenous claims to land and resource rights, and hypothetical victories by social and environmental justice movements in the global south, will save us. Also, that BC is in the right, fracking and the tar sands are bad, and Alberta needs to change from an extreme energy extractive economy to something less sh***y, for all our sakes. What I am supposed to do on a personal level short of sending letters to my MP or buying an electric vehicle or chaining myself to pipeline construction equipment, though, I am none the wiser having read this book.

I got this book through Goodreads giveaways (thank you Penguin, Goodreads and Naomi Klein :) - it was my very first try at giveaways and I got lucky. Having read previous books by Ms. Klein I was so excited about this one. Both of the previous were eye opening, thought provoking and engaging and this one is nothing less. Even more, you can see the author's matureness as the book is meticulously organized (the facts and the extensive research need no special mentioning as they are something we grew to expect from Ms. Klein).This book deals with tough questions. It is also in a way a continuation of The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism. As shocking as The Shock Doctrine was and however important things discussed there, it still had an air of something out of our own control. Forces of certain governments, secret agencies and the liberal capitalism itself felt more like a natural catastrophes then something ordinary people can deal with and change (metaphor intended as This Changes Everything deals exactly with natural catastrophes and how we can respond to them). And the answer to the question of global warming is where this book shines - it manages to explain how we can ourselves - everyday and ordinary people - change everything by acting locally and in our own neighbourhood. It brings back the basics of humanity - care about your neighbours and care about the nature - and shows that they can mean much more and be a powerful weapon, not only against inequalities but also for the continuous and improved existence. The very introduction to this book should be a compulsory read for anybody wanting to make a meaningful life in modern society. In itself it explains the problem and the underlying cause and also suggests an answer. The rest of the book gives arguments and strengthens the belief that we are on the precipice with change being not only imminent but required too. During the course of my reading, the very newspapers articles being published came to prove certain facts in the book (e.g. article about Gates foundation: http://www.grain.org/article/entries/... and No Messiahs: The Green Billionaires Won't Save Us)One part of the book I found implicitly problematic is the one that deals with the Blockadia movement. Though it is obvious that it is a right kind of movement, the way Ms. Klein presented it gives impression that only people involved in it love their surroundings enough to actually do something. In reality it is painfully obvious that it is the combination of two facts: pollution coming to the developed west's own backyard and a glorious loophole found in treaties signed with indigenous nations long time ago. We were lucky that those two facts together provide significant stand for moving the fight where it really matters - to the owners of global corporations and governments of leading industrialized countries and upcoming successors. It is not true that things were different before and that people elsewhere (in less developed parts) love the land where they live any less. I am certain that Ms. Klein hasn't done that intentionally as her regards towards the movement and people fighting for their own rights everywhere are clear and have been that way forever, yet her huge enthusiasm about it made others seem insignificant. It is a presentation thing and I believe that it will be changed in the future editions.The ending of the book provides a long lasting inspiration for changing our own attitudes. It is a clear moral voice pointing out that to deal with climate changes today means to finish the process of liberation. We still have a legacy of continued discrimination, double standards and entrenched poverty and it is mirrored in the way we treat Earth. Hopefully, the solution to one problem will solve others too. This Changes Everything is in the first place an honest book. It is also a guide to a better life - individually and together as a species with the planet we inhabit. Thank you Ms. Klein for showing us the way.

I have long been convinced by the science that climate change and global warming is occurring through the effects of human activity. Teaching science for over twenty years, very often organising pupils’ investigations into the “greenhouse effect” left me and my teen age charges in no doubt that the same warming could occur through an accumulation of so-called greenhouse gases over the Earth; carbon dioxide CO2, methane CH4 and water vapour being the principle gases involved. “This Changes Everything” from Naomi Klein is an inspiring and momentous book that should be read by all who care about the environment and future generations. It is written in the most accessible and persuasive fashion, for layman and expert, with comprehensive research and accurate revelations about corporate individuals, possible corruption, and collusion between major organisations – on both sides of the climate change argument. I imagine that I was not the only reader to be surprised to find disclosures in the book about suspicious discredit of scientific proof of climate change by some who stand to benefit from such practices, even financing such apalling behaviour. Even if the science about climate change causes some people to still doubt that it is indisputable proof that the damage is being caused by human activity, and not just due to natural climate cycling, we must surely still ask is it worth the risk? There is no doubt industry is addicted to using fossil fuels as a source of energy, and that the developed, and developing world, is addicted to its use of electricity, through its ever growing range of devices requiring electrical energy. There could well be an argument to reassess the ways of the capitalist world to free us from our addiction to electricity. But I do not think that is going to happen, notwithstanding some major catastrophe that forces the issue. Changing how we resource the provision of the energy rather than through fossil fuels should be a smaller task than completely changing modern societal living. So changing the behaviour of the big businesses providing the resources and sources that make electricity should be a reasonable thing to expect governments to bring about. Yes? Well maybe it’s not that easy.Naomi Klein’s most important book illustrates well that this question of changing big business regarding provision of “useful energy” is still deeply involved with politics, and those who claim it has much to lose by changing its practices. Governments which allow themselves to be pushed around by large corporate organisations instead of legislating on the issues that will affect future generations of its citizens are not acting in the best interests of the people. The energy business is intent on continuing to use fossil fuels, which everyone now knows, and this book well demonstrates is detrimental to the Earth and all life, including human, on it now and in the future. The author does not write only about doom and gloom for the future. She relates tale after tale about people around the world who achieved seemingly impossible change using a variety of peaceful methods. Leaders and policy makers everywhere know what the problems are but when will they act rather than procrastinate? To quote from the book:“It is slowly dawning on a great many of us that no one is going to step in and fix this crisis; that if change is to take place it will only be because leadership bubbled up from below.”We can only hope that the leader emerges and the change occurs before too long, before 2017 ideally, or else we may have another serious bubble bursting over us all sometime soon. I heartily recommend that all who care about the future of the Earth and our children read this book.

Let me first say I received this book through a giveway on Goodreads. That being said, I was really excited to read this book and to see it land on my doorstep a while ago. Why do I say a while ago? It took me forever to finish it.This doesn't mean it's not a good book. It is. And it discusses essential challenges regarding our climate that needed to get tackled yesterday (and it was by some, but not in anywhere the scale it needs to be adressed going forward). But it will certainly dispel a lot of the notions you thought you knew about the "struggle" and the possible victories or allies to the cause you read about in the news, ect. For instance, the environmental defense group that won a battle to protect an area from development in order to save a rare wild chicken species, and turns this victory into an abject failure when they decide to develop the site themselves so they can finance their action, extinguishing the species of chicken they were supposed to protect in the process. Or just how environment friendly the Virgin CEO really is (turns out, not that much).So I took a long time to read it because it was depressing me quite a bit, and Klein gets to the encouraging stuff late in the process (there is some encouraging, uplifting stuff in there, I assure you). I'm glad I read the book, and I hope you'll read it too. You need as much information as you can get about this subject.I'll say one thing however about the title or the general definition of the battle Klein uses. She depicts it as "climate vs capitalism." I think we're a bit too simplistic here. I would rather see "climate vs deregulated/unregulated capitalism." Some solutions Naomi Klein outlines in the book would work well in a capitalist system, albeit not a pure unadulterated one. A lot of the problems our society faces in tackling the climate issue stem from the lack of regulation, or the steamrolling over existing regulations by elected officials who do not truly represent their constituents but are slaves to the lobbies maintaining them in power. It would be far too simplistic to characterize that solely as a Republican problem in the U.S. (although they probably should bear most of the blame right now) since money in politics is sclerosing the entire apparatus. After all, Richard Nixon put together the EPA. So the GOP was not always against progress in this area. Anybody who drinks water and breathes air should be with the program, really, and it's truly weird to see so many people work against their own interests.No, I think what we have here is a deficit of democracy regardless of banners, and Klein's conclusions go towards a solution that will come from the people on the ground, and by that I mean local efforts by the most affected people snowballing into networked efforts and a greater action globally to push forward solutions (a lot of which we already have but won't implement for a range of reasons) and slow down our fall. The remaining question really is: will it be too late?I told you it can be a bit depressing to consider such questions, but it doesn't mean it's not essential to do so.

"This Changes Everything" explores the social, economic, and moral implications of global warming, and the urgent need to avoid catastrophic climate change. The book focuses on the human impacts of activities contributing both to the climate crisis and broader ecological devastation, and examines the scope of changes that could improve our collective chance of survival or radically reduce it. Using a journalistic narrative that is both personal and historical, author Naomi Klein traces the current crisis to the development of a worldview that denies the intrinsic value of life, both human and otherwise, treating all as objects to be found, molded, used, and discarded by people motivated only by their own success. According to Klein, this worldview, which underlies our dominant economic system, capitalism, is converting a replenishing, vibrant, life-supporting and life-driven system into its exact opposite. Replacing that worldview and the mechanisms based on it with something healthier is both a solution to the climate crisis, and a way to make the world generally a better place for most of its inhabitants. The book explores in detail how such an alternative worldview is being developed, using both modern and ancient attempts that have had varying degrees of success, and how its practical manifestations, evidenced by efforts based on its precursors, have the potential to avoid the catastrophe that looms over all of us. As Klein repeatedly points out, we don't have any time to waste (less than a handful of years). Efforts to tweak the existing economic and political systems have had marginal success, and people involved in them have been all-too-easily co-opted into compromises – and worse – that simply will not suffice to deal with a problem of this magnitude and urgency. Radical action may be all we have left.I found this book to be consistent with what I have learned and come to understand over more than a decade studying these issues. There is some information I was unaware of, such as some options being considered as worst-case geo-engineering "solutions" that may themselves be worse cases, and the scope of compromises that prominent environmental organizations have pursued. Overall, I found the book be well written and researched, and its arguments well made and worthy of serious consideration. What particularly resonated with me was Klein's case for having a frank and open, global debate about core values (as opposed to issue-specific prescriptions) among all people, not just their often-insulated leaders. Having spent several years in my thirties teasing out the values that I and others implicitly and often-unconsciously lived by, and spent more than a decade attempting to discern the fundamental dynamics and limitations of life and happiness, I came to realize that many of the problems we face are due to diverging opinions of what is ultimately valuable and how the world really works so those values can be implemented effectively. I'm beginning to get a handle on how to resolve this, and see "This Changes Everything" as a useful, insightful contribution to such an effort.

Excellent and critical commentary on the connections between climate change, capitalism, and environmentalism as it has been practiced for the past few decades. Clear in the conclusion that such practice is not working, and we need to change it from the bottom, because economic and political (and, yes, environmentalist) leaders are not going to do it quickly enough. This is a chronicle of a movement at the fetal stage of development (to which Klein aptly makes analogies) and a plea for attention, nurturing, awareness, education and involvement in order to take it to the next stage. What that next stage looks like was not clear to me, and may indeed not be clear to the people making such pleas, perhaps because we haven't actually ever done that next stage before. Analogies in terms of scope and depth of social change are drawn to the abolitionist movement, which has stretched over about two centuries and is still running. This movement needs to move even faster and spread even wider. It remains interesting, however, that those on the wrong side of abolition (wealthy, entitled, upper-class Western Civilization white males) are pretty much the same as those on the opposing side of the climate justice movement.Having read Klein's "Shock Doctrine" recently, I really see these two books as one evolving story that isn't done yet. Reading this book alone, I would have been looking for more of the astounding investigational depth into the status quo that Klein provided in "Shock Doctrine." Her depth of discussion on the connections between industry and politics in North America is adequate, but could have had more power by calling out specific donations and lobbies and the damaging, de-regulating legislation that those relationships produced. A key link to the the US military as the single largest US consumer of fossil fuels is made, but not explored much further. Some of this may have required repetition of points from "Shock Doctrine" but then, if repetition is required to draw further conclusions in an even larger context, I'm not averse to that larger combined perspective. That perspective is exactly what is needed to open so many eyes to the depth of change that is needed. Klein seems to stop just short of that level of (justified) outrage in her chronicle here, though. Together, "Shock Doctrine" and "This Changes Everything" are a nearly complete picture of what's wrong, and what we're up against in the industry-military-politics-economics-climate fight. Maybe her ongoing reporting efforts and next book can draw all of those together?I loved this book, don't get me wrong. I also wanted more depth, more scathing arguments, and more moral outrage at the (often corrupted) people and groups who insist on maintaining the status quo that is driving the need for a growing climate justice movement.

This is a disappointing book for someone like me who shares a lot of Klein's political views. It's too long and too flimsy, stringing together different vignettes with moral outrage rather than rigorous argument. Her examples are interesting and frequently original, as when she recounts how the Nature Conservancy became enmeshed with fossil fuel companies, or how Warren Buffett and Michael Bloomberg profit from fossil fuel investments despite their "climate activism". She can be good with the telling detail, like when she describes trade negotiations for the Trans Pacific Partnership, in which even vague, non-binding references to the environment and UNFCCC are removed from treaty provisions. Trade trumps the environment; the environment never trumps trade. And those details are well supported with all the footnotes.But all that footnoting isn't the same thing as having a tight argument. For instance, she never specifies what she means by "capitalism", though she seems to mean the neoliberal variant that's become increasingly dominant since the early eighties. But is the problem something inherent to the economic system or just politics? It's hard to tell. Ecological economists like Herman Daly get a mention, but she doesn't go into a single relevant proposition such as the impossibility of perpetual economic growth. She cites Germany many times for its renewable energy successes, but last time I checked, Germany was a capitalist country. She favours a steep carbon tax but is against cap-and-trade, though both measures are market-based policy instruments. Things like nuclear power are dismissed out of hand, while a single article from a Stanford prof proposing we can be 100% renewables worldwide by 2030 is uncritically accepted. This strikes me as hardly a cogent analysis.The real target isn't capitalism, but corporations and their enabling government partners. And she does a good job explaining why the climate views of Stephen Harper (I'm Canadian), the Koch brothers, etc. are not really about the climate at all, but just an extension of their political frame of reference. But why does she single out corporations and governments as the bad guys? She never blames consumers or voters, or non-Western actors for that matter, and I would argue that if you have agency, you have responsibility and therefore share the blame.Like Klein, I think incrementalism isn't going to solve the climate problem. CO2 emissions are up 61% worldwide since 1990, when climate negotiations really got started. I agree with her that we need strong political action from mass movements to make real progress. But this is not the book I would cite to convince anyone of that.

When it comes to global warming there are two groups of thought on the left. There is the political left which wishes to use global warming as an excuse to raise taxes. There is also the environmental left which views global warming as a serious threat to the planet and actually want to do what it would take to keep the planet below the scientist and global consensus of less than 2 degrees Celsius of warming. The political left loves to claim the aura of science and reason while they also claim that “there’s no contradiction between a sound environment and strong economic growth” (Barack Obama, Georgetown). Meanwhile the likes of Naomi Klein and Bill McKibben argue that “growth-based economic logic is now in fundamental conflict with atmospheric limits” (This Changes Everything loc 1615).Both the political left and environmental left view climate change as an issue through which they can enact their political agenda. Barack Obama wants to tax oil companies to raise government revenues and increase the size of government. Naomi Klein uses climate change as a means to enact her entire world view, which means destroying both globalism and capitalism. Klein is abundantly clear in her book that she views capitalism and globalism as enemy number one for the environment and must be destroyed. The stated goal to avoid major consequences of global warming is to keep temperature rise below 2 degrees Celsius. Where this stated goal collides with economics is that energy companies have already discovered and have intentions to burn roughly 5 times the amount of carbon necessary to raise global temperatures above 2 degrees. This means that not only can energy companies not find additional carbon energy but they must be forced to keep trillions of dollars worth of energy buried in the ground. In order for this to happen, not only would capitalism have to be tossed aside, but likely so would representative democracy. Those trillions of dollars in the ground mean jobs and economic progress for billions across the globe, and no one is going to vote for economic ruin.Klein also seems to think that global warming is an actual threat to the human species, something that I have seen no serious source claim. If Klein’s proposed pathway is the only way to avoid catastrophic global warming then there is no possible way we will avoid catastrophic global warming. (If you read this I am sorry about any grammatical errors, I didn’t take the time to review/edit)

I appreciate that Naomi Klein, in her newest book, This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. the Climate, stresses the urgency of the climate change situation that we all face, yet recognizes the nearly impossible challenge that is implementing real and immediate change to avert what is surely a fast-approaching global disaster of epic proportions. Having read No Logo and The Shock Doctrine: The Rise of Disaster Capitalism and been inspired by both, it is this reader’s opinion that Klein’s newest book reads more sadly than the previous two. I say this because the scope of the problem that Klein describes is so huge and so complicated, requiring such a radical shift from the so-called status quo, that solving it seems virtually impossible.Klein has, of course, made a career of reporting from the front lines of movements for political and social justice, so one cannot discount her optimism that the problem of climate change is one worth solving (and that can be solved, if approached in the right way). For sure, in her previous writings and in this one, as well, she describes victories against seemingly impossible odds by those who have faced grave challenges no less serious than the one that we collectively face now. However, climate change is a different kind of challenge that will (and, perhaps, already does) affect everyone. Considering the scope and complexity of this problem that we face, the sadness that is evident in the tone of this book left me feeling that even the book’s author may be coming to terms with the idea that it’s too late to hope for the best because the worst, which we should have been preparing for, is now upon us. Read this book and reflect upon its message. Then, let’s take the medicine that Klein prescribes and hope we’re not too late.

The problem of global climate change is beyond urgent. Climate change poses an existential threat to life as we know it, and it is staring us in the face. Our national leaders – not just the U.S., although its example has been pathetic - ought to have egg on their faces for promoting a status quo that, decades after a “commitment” to limit global temperature increase to two degrees Celsius by 2100, has taken us headlong in exactly the opposite direction.The problem is, of course, that too many governments are bought and paid for by a fossil fuel industry which, no matter how clear the evidence that we need to leave carbon in the ground, is fighting for its continued dominance in the global marketplace.Klein speaks of two factors that have exacerbated the problem of climate change. First, after three decades of failing to take meaningful countermeasures, we have come to the point where meeting the stated goal of two degrees Celsius will require massive shocks to the “normal” workings of capitalism and global trade, and to the ideology of nations blindly pursuing maximum economic growth, in competition with one another, on an annual basis. Second, in their struggle to extend the era of coal, oil, and gas as the engine of our economy, these behemoth fossil fuel companies are investing in – even doubling down on – extreme extraction technologies (like tar sands, hydraulic fracturing, and mountaintop removal) that have accelerated our dumping of carbon dioxide and methane into the earth’s atmosphere, as well as putting our water supply at risk and endangering the health and safety of millions.I don’t mean to steal Naomi Klein’s thunder (as if I could possibly do that). There’s far more to This Changes Everything, and none of it gets any less alarming. The devil is in the details, which Klein recounts so compellingly. In fact, she writes, the dilemma of climate inaction is part and parcel of decades of growing income inequality and the modern assault by multinational corporations upon our democracy. We can’t solve one of these threats without confronting the others.Ignore this book at your peril. It is one of the most important literary works of the twenty-first century.

A compelling book, researched and nuanced. Able to be both starkly negative and encouraging.The premise is that a world view change is essential in order to combat the climate change that has already begun; that world view involves visions of humanity, nature, and economics. The first section explores how the climate crisis, which needs public solutions, hit at a time when the public arena had been eviscerated. (That evisceration is the topic of her Shock Doctrine. It helped that I had recently read it.) Klein analyzes various kinds of denial, including that of people who look away because the problem seems so huge. Interestingly, she noted that climate-change deniers on the right see the consequences of action--radical change to economic structures and capitalist values--more clearly than the liberal counterparts who tried such free market driven moves as cap and trade emissions. The second section explores green groups that merged with big business, billionaires who offer money for green solutions while also investing in fossil fuels, and technical solutions proposed. The latter, with their few pros and many cons, can be contemplated only if one is willing to see some geographic areas and their people as expendable.The third section surveys climate actions, indigenous peoples' rights movements and legal battles, and a change in thinking from the right to extract to the need to replenish. The chapter on dangers of chemical spills to eggs and embryos is particularly moving. Once again the limitation of impact statements based only on adults, sometimes even only on adult males, is apparent. Her concluding chapters on the history of social movements, what they accomplished and what they left unfinished provides a way to look at potential climate movements. The topic is hard; the prose readable.While climate movements are essential--and many issues can be pulled into this umbrella--they must include the world view change away from free market ideology. Let's hope it is a paradigm shift we, collectively, can make. In time.

Reading this book has changed my life. This book is the first book I've read from the Ontario Library Association's Evergreen selections for 2015. Naomi Klein is such an important voice for Canada that this book was on my to-read list well before it was nominated though. I enjoyed reading this book through Audible.com's selection so I listened to about 7 hours a week which was wonderful because it has a lot of important information about climate change that are combined with unfamiliar issues such as economics, world trade, environmental law, industrialization, and indentured slavery that I needed to digest in smaller pieces. Klein manages to put all of these issues together into one book and concludes that if we can't manage to adjust our culture of consumption that we don't have a chance of stopping global warming. More importantly though, that we need to start making right the crimes that we have committed through industrialization and globalization and make reparations to developing nations that are still disadvantaged by centuries of colonial actions. At home in Canada, Klein argues that we need to demand a higher minimum wage so that people can stop taking McJobs for shitty companies who continue to put capitalism first and human needs and the environment as distant seconds. In a deeply personal chapter, Klein reveals that her concerns for climate change exploded during her struggles with infertility and points to our dramatic increases in infertility and disease as the red flag symptoms that we continue to ignore by believing in the capitalism-driven pharmaceuticals instead. In summary: I learned a lot. As a secondary school teacher-librarian, I will carry this book in my library but it isn't going to be an easy sell. However, as a research tool it will be phenomenal and I will bring bits and pieces of it out to stimulate inquiry research and for discussion for years to come.

With most of the political screeds I consume, I find myself thinking about them in two- (Congressional) and four- (Presidential) year terms. Not so with Klein’s trenchant call to action. Klein examines the incompatibility between our current zealous capitalism and the continuation of life as we know it on planet Earth, and strikes an appropriately baleful tone throughout. Our tendencies and habits are both so baked into our way of life and yet so harmful that we are headed for a calamity, either of our comforts or something far less weatherable and reversible. When I read about other issues that engage my sympathies, I tend to think “A better President/Congress will enact this, if we’re lucky,” but the warning Klein issues is that we are already past the tipping point, and even if we took drastic measures we might not avert the disaster she warns of. And because we are nowhere near the point of coordinating for such massive austerity measures, I wonder if there’s much hope for us at all, aside from the magical thinking of global engineering that Klein views with appropriate suspicion.Climate change is something like healthcare reform or educational policy for which I toe the liberal line but which has never been forefront of my concerns about society or the world. I live in the city, I recycle, I take public transportation, I don’t travel much, I buy second-hand clothing and get my books from the library, but I’m sure there is a lot more I could be doing. I’m not sure it will keep the rivers from boiling off the land or the seas from turning subacid, but I’m scared enough to investigate.As with her other works, Klein is brutal, thorough, and brilliant. I missed her acerbity but as always appreciated the monumental effort she puts into calling our attention to that which matters.

I wanted to read “This Changes Everything” as soon as it came out and it really did not disappoint. This is not a book about the science of climate change, but rather the economics of climate change and how, in Klein’s words, the climate is at war with our economic system. The main virtue of this book is the angle from which climate change and the global efforts to fight it are presented; indeed, I am grateful to Naomi Klein for framing, in such a clear way, our (weak) response to climate change in a perspective that moves away from the mainstream discourse and tackles its flaws from the roots. Moving from the fact that climate change is the biggest challenge of our century, Klein describes it also as an opportunity (that has to be taken very quickly!) to change our economic system and address other crucial issues, as poverty and rising inequality. The measures to fight climate change entail enormous potential for the change of our society, endangered by the same unrestricted consumption and “extractivist” mindset that are irreparably altering the planetary balance. As always, Klein’s work is heavily researched and backed up by documents and interviews and she goes further than just explaining the depth and gravity of the problem, but offers concrete example from different communities, states and cities demonstrating that different pathways are possible. “The challenge, then, is not simply that we need to spend a lot of money and change a lot of policies; it’s that we need to think differently, radically differently, for those changes to be remotely possible. Right now, the triumph of market logic, with its ethos of domination and fierce competition, is paralyzing almost all serious efforts to respond to climate change.”

This book is extremely well researched, as are all Naomi Klein's books and articles. It's also what makes her works so scary to read. I am truly depressed after reading "Capitalism vs. the Climate". Capitalists have such a tight stranglehold on the entire world, and I just don't see much hope to save the planet so it's inhabitable by humans. My hope is dashed even further because I don't think it is possible to make the kinds of changes in how we live a great deal of our lives in time to limit the damage global warming is already causing. Each chunk of coal, each drop of oil, each cylinder of gas that comes out of the ground, every power switch we turn on, moves us one step closer to a planet that will starve and dehydrate us and so many other species to death. I don't see how we avoid a 6th mass extinction with the leaders we have in power now and in the near future. We have to act now, and I don't see how it will be possible to act now enough to stop the apocalypse.I will keep working toward stopping the warming. We need the type of efforts that went into the allies winning WWII and implementing the Marshall Plan after the war. We need that kind of all-hands-on-deck if we are to save ourselves and our future. I just pray my son's world will still be livable.

I won this book in a Goodreads giveaway. It is very scary and impressive journalism. It explains climate change science and extensively explains the state of CO2 buildup in the atmosphere. It also describes many political, social, economic, and scientific aspects surrounding climate change itself and ways to slow, curtail, stop or combat it. It does this exhaustively and is extremely up-to-date. Many of us know much about this crisis and find it daunting and terrifying. The book, however, shows what is successfully being done to combat the crisis and what can be done. The book has hope and guidance to balance much of the anger and despair intrinsic to this issue. Klein ties climate change and its slowing/solution with the nature of unfettered capitalism and current predominant western economic theory/philosophy. Though she does this effectively, tying this book in with her previous work, it could be more thoroughly explained; I feel I could appreciate and understand this volume better, having read  The Shock Doctrine . Overall, this was excellent, and really should be a must read for students, and frankly, people in general.

Elizabeth Kolbert’s review of This Changes Everything in the NY Review of Books is a worthwhile read, not just to get a sense of the book but as a piece of journalism in its own right: http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archi...Kolbert’s argument, which some others have echoed, is that, yes, this is an important political moment that Klein is perhaps naming (that the critique of say, transnational labor exploitation has its biggest ally in some new environmentalism), but what we ought to be for rather than against (or rather, how we might get to what we are for) is less clear. I worry too about the use of “climate” instead of bringing in a much larger picture than global warming of anthropogenic disturbance. Perhaps “Anthropocene” is a more useful metaphor than global warming, as one of the biggest parts of the story of industrialization/colonialism is simply land use change. Check out: http://www.hkw.de/en/programm/projekt...

Klein paints a very, very, very grim picture of the mess that unbridled global capitalism, an uncontrolled and utterly rapacious fossil fuel industry and a co-opted Big Green "environmental" community has landed us in.She sees some hope that the reality of climate change — droughts, floods, melting glaciers, ocean acidification, huge and devastating storms, rising sea levels — is starting to awaken a massive global will to shut down the oil, coal and gas companies and to wrest control of our governments from the gobblizers who now have arrogated to themselves the right to make the rules without any reference to democracy, decency or even the laws of physics. I hope she's right, because if THIS DOES CHANGES EVERYTHING there is a chance that we can create a world based on the give and take of life instead of the take and take and take and take of capitalism and the extractive industries that drive it. If this DOESN'T CHANGE EVERYTHING everything is going to change anyway, but we will all be choking on the smoke of a burning and dying planet.

An optimistic Naomi Klein? That may seem an oxymoron! But I loved this book for its insistent rallying call that mitigating climate change and reforming unregulated capitalism is the same battle. “The climate movement offers an overreaching narrative in which everything from the fight for good jobs to justice for migrants to reparations for historical wrongs like slavery and colonialism can all become part of the grand project of building a nontoxic shockproof economy before it’s too late.”And, similarly, from Miya Yoshitani from the Asian Pacific Environmental Network based in the SF area, “The climate justice fight here in the U.S. and around the world is not just a fight against the biggest ecological crisis of all time, it is the fight for a new economy, a new energy system, a new democracy, a new relationship to the planet and to each other, for land, water, and good sovereignty , for indigenous rights, for human rights and dignity for all people. When climate justice wins, we win the world we want.”Yes!

Please read this book. While it is hard to find a climate change denier these days (except in the United States Congress), most of us are still pretty adept at looking away. But if the planet is sliding towards ruin (it is), then we owe it to ourselves to at least build a little awareness into our lives as we enjoy the scenery on the way down.Once you do, it's hard not to get angry; and indeed, you get the sense right away that Naomi Klein is pissed. But her tone (exasperated hair pulling just beneath the surface of her meticulous journalism) is not off-putting. Rather, as her dear reader, you start feeling the rage as well. Because the real problem isn't climate change, so much as the economic and political systems that aggressively force us along our doomed path.In fact, her reporting is so convincing that her we-can-still-stop-this attitude is substantially less so. But perhaps if enough people stop looking away, things can drastically change. So yeah, please read this book.

Oh no, I'm turning green, and it's Naomi Klein's fault! For many years, I was turned off the green movement because of its apparent domination by bourgeois whipper-snappers who used it to be sanctimonious about the number of categories into which they divided their rubbish, and used that as an excuse to ignore poverty and fundamentalism. Klein succeeds in linking the destruction of the Earth inextricably with market fundamentalism, and in showing that neither is invincible. OK, I'm convinced. Towards the end of the book, she gets tempted towards Mother Earth woo by her own fertility problems, but eventually manages to distinguish the scientific method from the abuse of science. I suspect that if she knew more about pre-Columbian societies, she would be less inclined to romanticise their descendants. Overall, however, it is a meticulously researched, clear and well argued book that everyone should read while they can.

Thoughtful, well researched, and intelligent examination of the climate crisis. Klein reminds us that time is running out to prevent catastrophic climate change, and looks at opportunities to make significant changes that will be needed to halt the warming trends. She pulls no punches, revealing how "big Green" environmental groups have made weak compromises influenced by the funding they receive(d) from the fossil fuel industry. Pointing out that the poor and powerless are bearing the brunt of the damage developed countries have caused, she calls for us to provide support to aboriginal groups trying to preserve their rights, to countries trying to develop without depending on fossil fuels. Throughout the book, I alternated between anger, disillusionment, overwhelming helplessness and determination to work toward the changes we must make.

This insightful, inciting book has the capacity both to crush and to encourage, which is rare in anything. It simultaneously declares DEFCON 1 and gives hope, sharing personal anecdotes and experiences along the way. Although it is very dense, and many times made me so angry I had to put it down, it was not the book itself that made me angry, but the situation. It compels action, both physical and psychological, asking us to rethink our society and the ways in which it is failing us. Not everything is wrong, not everything is bad, but plenty enough is corrupt to upend the system. Klein asks us to look honestly at ourselves and our society, and to find a better path into a better, brighter, more equitable world. This is an excellent book.This book was won from the publisher through the Goodreads First Reads program. Thank you!

The most important book I've ever read. We're running out of time to change our ways and if we don't the effects will be devastating. That's reality. "We know that if we continue on our current path of allowing emissions to rise year after year, climate change will change everything about our world. Major cities will very likely drown, ancient cultures will be swallowed by the seas, and there is a very high chance that our children will spend a great deal of their lives fleeing and recovering from vicious storms and extreme droughts. And we don’t have to do anything to bring about this future. All we have to do is nothing. Just continue to do what we are doing now, whether it’s counting on a techno-fix or tending to our gardens or telling ourselves we’re unfortunately too busy to deal with it." ~ page 4, This Changes Everything: Capitalism vs. The Climate by Naomi Klein

Another volley from Naomi Klein. As with previous Naomi Klein books I've read, it's well-written, well-researched, and well-argued, and the sort of book that needs to be published. Now, that being said, I would like something a bit more empirical, but she's writing for a more general audience, so that's probably not the case. Also, she romanticizes indigenous cultures in a way that comes off more than a bit cringey and cloying. While indigenous knowledge and lifeways certainly merit respect, when Klein writes about them, she comes off as an archetypal white liberal trying to extract some kind of revolutionary potential from the other. But, all things considered, that gripe only applies to 10 percent of the book at most. The rest is a deeply compelling argument for how the climate fight must be intrinsically anti-neoliberal.

Naomi Klein’s book THIS CHANGES EVERYTHING: CAPITALISM VS THE CLIMATE is the most cogent analysis of the climate crisis we are facing I have so far encountered. While there is some science included in the early part of the book, she is most interested in addressing the ways in which saving the earth and continuing to practice capitalism as we know it, are incompatible. She believes (and I agree) that the only way to salvage a habitable planet is to revise our thinking radically and move beyond the ‘extractivism’ and growth-at-all-costs mentality that is currently so pervasive. It is a tall order, and I am not sure I believe it can be done, but I applaud her for putting these ideas out there, and also for the extensive research that has gone into this book. Fingers crossed that people will receive her message.

i would like more people to know of this book, read this book and be able to pull information out of this book when they need it.I learnt more about the social complexity than from other books on the topic though I'd recommend reading climate science in other books.The concept of big green is well laid out. If it is mentioned in other books, I've not been exposed to it before. Even if you don't read the whole book there is just such good writing on specific topics every flagging reader should flick straight to the material that interests them before giving up, plus one extra being the section on indigenous resistance. It will change the way you think.I felt the idea of renewables being ready to completely replace fossil fuels overly optimistic but maybe that is part of the required deindustrialisation.When it comes to the politics, this book is second to none.

This book on climate change — what is being done to prevent it as well as to keep it going — is very troubling, but the huge cloud does have a silver lining: Klein believes that a battle over world views could change the way we see things and lead to radical change before it’s too late. The “everything” of the title means that everything in our (U.S./Canadian) society (except democracy) has to change in order to stop climate change, everything must be questioned and seen anew, especially the role of the ideology of free market capitalism, which allows extraction without responsibility or regeneration. Klein goes on too long about liberal billionaires, but I was amazed how few places I skimmed. This was even better than I expected, and Klein more convincing; a must read for every thoughtful person.

I won this book in a giveaway from Goodreads. My first so was very excited. Naomi Klein is one of my favs. Read the Shock Doctrine and it changed my perception of the world. This book is a detailed and personal account of the politics of climate change. While I pretty much agree with her conclusions. I am not too hopeful for the outcome. Like she says, Just because you have the right and you are right, it does not translate to the rich and powerful in any real way. It is a captivating read and an essential one if you care about our planet.Hope everyone who is interested gets a chance to listen to Klein on Charlie Rose. If you haven't the time to read her book, this interview will be a valuable tool to help inform.

This is one of the most politically important books I have ever read.A compelling and comprehensive account of climate change: how we got here, why it matters, and how we may be able to get out of this situation if all of us begin to act right now.The topic is heavy going (as it should be) at times, from indigenous battles against predatory fossil fuel companies, to whole nations (Nauru) that have been systematically destroyed on a social, economic, and environmental level by the devastating inequality linked to a capitalist system fuelled by non-renewable energy.Read this book, and then take its advice to find out more about how together we can create a mass movement of green initiatives that just might have a chance of changing things before it really is too late.

This is an important book. I will not say it was a positive book or one filled with means/methods the average (first world monied) person (on Goodreads) can employ to mitigate climate change or even get off the teat of capitalism. But it did couch the larger problem of climate change *versus* capitalism as an unfortunate one of timing: the industrial age was the source of both. She states, more positively, that this is a human rights issue that, because of its scale, wipes out and carries along all other human rights issues...it swamps them all. What we are left with is, can we afford to continue to look away? The answer is no, but...

I am biased as Naomi Klein was one of the first economic writers that wrote approachable books that I read as kid. Her new book unlike the numerous copies of the Shock Doctrine is not the perfect title to explain modern capitalism to your republican neighbors. Instead it is the book for the hippies in your life. It contains. what is probably the most well researched study of the impact of our economics on the environment and how those same economics will be part of the solution to the terrifying problem.

This book does change everything! After reading it I can't go back to life as usual, it has motivated me to start working on climate change initiatives in my town. This book clearly outlines the issues around climate change and the pressing need for the world to wean itself off the use of fossil fuels and find renewable sources of energy. Klein has thoroughly researched her subject and provides lots of supporting research to substantiate her argument. This book is a must read and a call to action.

I understand that climate change is real; I accept that human activity is responsible; and I believe we should be doing everything we can to stop churning harmful emissions into the atmosphere. And yet this book, which is subtitled "Capitalism vs. the Climate," actually made me question these beliefs. To put it simply, Klein has made her argument in such a way--with not even a nod toward rhetorical balance--that it becomes difficult to believe many of the assertions she makes.See my full review here: Review of This Changes Everything

Exceptional. The must-read book on climate change and how we got there, and what we need to do, right now. Very uncomfortable reading, especially for those with more conservative mindsets, and I'm not sure that I agree with all her conclusions or suggested actions - but then again, I'm forced to really think about it. And she offers hope... but the scale of changes necessary is daunting. Anyway, I've started on my own steps, it really is that clear a call to action. Essential reading.

It's so disappointing to see how our public schools have failed us. I've spent all my life immersed in scientific research, and have even been an advocate for the environment since the 60's. However, what is being sold to the public as environmentalism today is sadly not. Note that the author claims no scientific background, she is an activist and a writer. Hardly a credible voice for this very divesive and hot subject. I fear the author will (and intends to) inflame the poorly informed.

A poignant analysis of the issue of global warming from every possible angle. One thing that amazes me about Klein's writing is how she manages to take a complex subject matter like this and show how all its different components are related.

This was an interesting look at the world and some of its problems. The ideas in this book occasionally made me angry (as they were designed to do). Climate change and the human footprint on the planet is a big deal and I am not going to argue about that. The solutions this author offers are over the top in a way it will be hard to implement.

The only book you should read this week! Already better than No Logo, after 15 years of research Klein sets out the facts about climate change. This is a well researched book and everything is referenced so you can check the facts for your self and read the disbelievers arguements if you wish.

"Basically, if you care about the environment, if only a little bit you should read this book." Incredible! Disturbing! Detailed! Readable. This should be on everyone's reading list for this year. Leave it too long, and it might be too late.

Can I give this a 10? And I didn't even agree with everything she said, and it was heavy to read. But because of its central message that extraction is killing our planet, and it will take communities to take their land and their resources back.
Extremely deep, well researched and inspiring. This really does change everything.
every activist should read this book

trenchant. naomi klein is, along with bill mckibben, the most persuasive and clearheaded writers on the climate situation we have.
